thread.title: Mining downturn affecting FIFO workers rosters
thread.title_full: Mining downturn affecting FIFO workers rosters

author: EMILY MOULTON
title: Mining downturn affecting FIFO workers rosters
text:
WHILE the mining downturn has left thousands of fly-in-fly-out (FIFO) workers out of a job, another costly consequence is beginning to emerge.
Some FIFOs who have either managed to keep their position or found a job at another site claim they have been forced to take pay cuts and work punishing rosters.
And this is despite a West Australian Parliamentary Inquiry recommending earlier this year that rosters be made more family-friendly.
According to counselling services in WA, the recent mass redundancies have scared many into accepting worse conditions, and it’s beginning to affect their health.
More than 25,000 fulltime jobs have been lost in WA’s mining industry since the peak of the boom.
Carolyn and Ray Midwood, of FIFO Counselling, told news.com.au that while there had been a decline in demand for their services in recent months, the message they were receiving from clients was that their situation had worsened.
“The biggest thing that is happening at the moment is that their rosters are increasing,” Mr Midwood explained. “So the time away from home is increasing and their time back is changing.”
FIFO workers’ are rostered to work in blocks. Two weeks on and one week off is considered the most family-friendly arrangement. However, more FIFOs are being forced to work four weeks on and one week off as the mining downturn starts to bite.
“Two in ones are going to three in ones and some have gone to four in ones. That’s what we are hearing," Mr Midwood said.
“They are having less time back home and more time at work.”
Atlas Iron’s Mount Webber site in Western Australia. Source: Supplied
It is this rostering system, coupled with other social factors associated with the FIFO life, that the authors of a report into a spate of nine suicides among FIFO workers during a 12-month period in WA believe needs to change.
In June, a WA parliamentary committee that examined the deaths found that while it couldn’t confirm the nine suicides were directly linked to FIFO work, they did conclude the lifestyle increased a person’s risk of mental health issues.
They recommended that a new code of practice on FIFO work arrangements be introduced to address rosters and the impact of fatigue on mental health
WA has one of the largest FIFO workforces in Australia. Despite the mass redundancies, it has been estimated there are still about 60,000 people who continue to fly in and fly out for work.
Mrs Midwood said those who have managed to keep their jobs or found new ones felt pressured into accepting what was on offer or learn new skills in order to keep their job.
“There is a lot of insecurities and anxieties about ‘when am I going to be made redundant’,” she explained. “If there is a position to go for, there’s a lot of pressure on site to upskill. It’s sort of like an uneven playing field now.
“I have a female client who has been told, ‘If you don’t like it, leave’.”
Rio Tinto Group workers from the West Angelas iron ore mine prepare to fly out. Picture: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg Source: Supplied
Nicole Ashby, of the FIFO Families support network, said out-of-work FIFOs were either upskilling in order to pick up another FIFO job, or they were returning to their previous industries.
“It seems people are picking up jobs in other sectors that are still FIFO so they might be jumping onto the construction jobs that are booming in the Northern Territory or Queensland,” she said.
“And some are getting work on other sites within the Pilbara.”
While demand for private emotional counselling services has dropped, there has been an increase in those seeking financial advice.
And WA Financial Counsellors’ Association executive officer Charles Brown said he expected demand to increase in coming months.
“It’s a bit alarming what traditionally happens. It’s a bit like a snake: They have swallowed all this problem and it takes a long time for it to work through the snake,” he said. “Because people were beginning to be laid off prior to Christmas, we were only receiving people slowly in dribs and drabs. It does take a while for people to use up the savings they had or to become, it’s sad to say, desperate enough to seek help.
“It’s that initial shock. It takes a little while for people to get over. And then it’s the shame and pride and all those other emotional type of things that force people to come and seek help.
“A lot of guys come back depressed. They used to be the big chief and suddenly they end up having to do the dishes.”
Mr Brown said recent increases in utility prices and other cost of living items was adding further pressure on FIFO families who are struggling to cope with high mortgages.
“One of the other things that has happened is the bankruptcy rate in WA has gone up. It is one of two regions that have increased. They have actually gone down in other states,” Mr Brown said. The dark side of FIFO 0:44 Play video
Working in a highly paid job as a fly-in-fly-out worker in WA can come at a high price.
